results.notes:
Two of these long stalked ruffled orange mushrooms were found growing from a rotten conifer (larch?) stump in a swamp. The one shown was on wet, mossy wood, the other a bit higher on the stump.
The larger cap (shown) was about 30 by 25 mm and the stalk about 70 mm.
The other was about 25 by 25 and 55 mm in comparison.
The stalk was narrow, widest bottom and top, had a spiral twist, was narrowly hollow, and had a basal mycelial tuft.
No distinctive odor, flavor, or bruising was noted.
Spore print scant to none.

results.notes:
Group of about 10-12 growing in brushy area surrounding a smallish oak.
A collection of what is certainly the same taxon (collected in same exact location) was submitted to FunDiS last year and the ITS matched sequences labeled “Amanita crenulata.” Evidence seems to be mounting to support a claim that Amanita crenulata fruit bodies exhibit a fairly elastic morphology and that the time-window for fruiting encompasses much more than mid-fall, which is when I find the (generally shorter) ones with champagne-colored caps and UV-deposits more powdery. The warm-weather version seems to have caps a more lively/brighter yellow with paler cap margin.
I first started finding this species on my property under mature white pine; only a few fruit bodies annually, usually late in the season. The species seems to have spread to young oaks that have sprung up during the past 20 years. In the case of the ones seen here, the oak was likely not eyt even an acorn 20 years ago. I have watched it grow for years; early on I had made it a point to avoid mowing it.

results.notes: This mushroom is growing in our backyard in Buena Park, not far from Knotts Berry Farm. A similar mushroom grew in this same area about a year ago and lived for a couple months before I finally tore it up out of curiosity. That one was similarly misshapen and was very solid and firm, much as this one currently feels. I would describe the firmness like a well cooked steak. This one is very close to the ground so I am not able to see the underside. It does not appear to have those “gills” like I see in grocery store type mushrooms. It’s hard to tell if it’s growing from a single stem or not. When pushing a ruler around the underside of it, the ruler can only go under it about 1 inch before hitting something solid. This one started growing about 2 weeks ago. The dark brown spots on it started as what looked very much like a bootprint, possibly from our gardeners. The neighbors next door used to have a tree on the other side of this wall about 5 years ago…I’m not sure what species. The grassy area where this is growing is often shaded from the wall and there is a sprinkler near by, so it is often damp. Los Angeles Mycological Society suggested this is a polypore and encouraged me to post it here for further ID.

results.notes:
-Ecology: gregarious-cespitose; within 10m of a lakeshore in a natural setting; nearby tree species: Pinus contorta, Alnus incana ssp. tenuifolia, Salix sp., Tsuga mertensiana
-Pileus: 15-35 mm; conical becoming broadly umbonate; margin strongly inrolled becoming decurved; dry, silky; uniformly dark lilac-brown when young, lightening somewhat to uniform lilac chestnut brown; hygrophanous, fading to light brown
-Lamellae: adnexed to notched; hidden by inrolled margin/cortina until maturity; lt. rusty brown becoming dark rusty brown
-Cortina: evanescent leaving faint annular zone at apex
-Stipe: 10-15mm X 30-70mm; dry, silky to appressed fibrillose; widened medially, tapering at the base; whitish fibrils over a dull brown context; context: light brown, dark brown at base
-Odor: mild, slight spicy

Stalks were variably hollow.
There was a distinct odor which I can’t name, and no distinct flavor was noted.
Few to no spores were obtained.
On 9-16 I again collected and obtained white spore prints.

results.notes:
Mature fruiting body beneath Sitka Spruce and Western Hemlock.
Elevation: Sea level.
Extensive dark blue staining where sliced.
Cap: areolate with texture of large grain sandpaper.
Stem: tapering, more slender at base than apex.
Dense reticulation at apex(upper stem).
*this collection has a bit of reticulation at stem base, as well. That fact, coupled with some distinct reddish tones in middle and base of stem points toward Caloboletus frustosus as being a very possible label for this collection. I Harvested a large portion of cap and dehydrated slices/bagged for herbarium collection.
Interested to sequence material from this one and see if this indeed turns out to be C. frustosus.
Bagged dried slices with desiccant pack to ensure safe long term storage.

results.notes: Found near mid day in a shady/sun spotted area close to some Pines and Oak trees with small scattered group around the specimen. After consulting others and comparing pictures of other sp-AR01 specimens observed on here, Substrate picked from is pebbly/muddy as is the rest of MS. No scent, sticky enough to hear my finger separate from the cap. No staining/bruising upon cutting the stem. Spore print revealed white spores similar to A. Jacksonii or A. Ceasarea. These pictures are free to use for whatever you see fit. Glad to just be contributing to the mycology/mushroom observer community above all else.
results.location_name: Hinds Co., Mississippi, USA

results.notes:
Aureoboletus sp.? Growing below mostly hardwoods at a forest edge in Etowah County, Alabama, US. September 2022.

Staining: None.
Odor: slightly like carrion.
KOH on cap: Very slowly turns olive.
KOH on flesh and pores: amber.
Ammonia: no reaction.
Ornamentation on stem: slight striations, but nothing pronounced.

The caps seemed somewhat viscid, but I wasn’t sure if the heavy rains played a part in that.

A little fuzzy on this genus (and most boletes), so any help is appreciated!
results.location_name: Etowah Co., Alabama, USA

results.notes:
Tubes are brown an about 30 mm deep (max), the flesh was white/pale yellow at about 50 mm.
The flesh had the consistency of dense bread or dry sponge…strangely soft not at all what I was expecting.
The margin was very blunt and an odd yellow.
My only problem with calling this T. colossus is the host. This was grown in an area that was recently clear cut of all trees except pines (they were left untouched). This was growing in a pile of material that was primarily OAK but there were things such as magnolia, dogwood, cedar plus other typical North Florida forest trees.

EDIT: an analysis was done to confirm T. colossus.
